measured_by: difference between participants' mean policy rating and their rating of the A/B test
justification: "Following Meyer et al. (2019), we define an "A/B effect" as the difference between participants' mean policy rating and their rating of the A/B test."

measured_by: difference between participants' rating of their own lowest-rated policy and their rating of the A/B test
justification: "Following Heck et al. (2020; see also Mislavsky et al., 2019) we define "experiment aversion" as the difference between participants' rating of their own lowest-rated policy and their rating of the A/B test."

measured_by: rating pattern: A/B test rated 1–2 (inappropriate) while each policy rated 3–5 (neutral or appropriate) on the 5-point scale
justification: "'Experiment rejection' ... occurs when a participant rates the A/B test as inappropriate (1 or 2 on the 5-point scale) while also rating each policy as neutral or appropriate (3-5 on the scale)."

measured_by: difference between participants' rating of the A/B test and their mean policy rating
justification: "A 'reverse A/B effect' is the difference between participants' rating of the A/B test and their mean policy rating—that is, the degree to which the A/B test is rated higher than the policies (on average)."

measured_by: difference between participants' rating of the A/B test and their rating of their own highest-rated policy
justification: "'Experiment appreciation' is the difference between participants' rating of the A/B test and their rating of their own highest-rated policy."

measured_by: rating pattern: A/B test rated 4–5 (appropriate) while each intervention rated 1–3 (neutral or inappropriate) on the 5-point scale
justification: "'Experiment endorsement' occurs when a participant rates the A/B as appropriate (4 or 5 on the 5-point scale) while also rating each intervention as neutral or inappropriate (1-3 on the scale)."
